comments.commentBody:
#44, RM, Let's put it this way, Jews, Christians, and Muslims all trace their their history to Abraham. The all believe in the same deity, who is referred to as God. There are many prophets which are common to all three religions. Muslims have additional prophets; including Muhammad. LDS has additional prophets.

In the case of Jesus of Nazareth, also known as Jesus Christ, he was a devout Jew and was referred to many time sin the New Testament as "Rabbi"; a teacher. The first followers of Christ were people of the Jewish faith.

The three major monotheistic faiths have a great deal in common. Unfortunately, people focus on the difference, not the commonality. It is for this reason wars have been fought almost continuously in the name of religion fro over 2000 years. And why this blog conversation exhibits these differences. Suffice it to say, your posting meant in jest, actually has some logical basis in fact. Finally, I strongly disagree with the assertion that any mainstream faith is a cult. Dr. Jeffers also referred to Hinduism, Shintosim, Buddism, Taosim and other eastern religions as cults, as well (religions which comprise 1/3 of the population of the planet). His view is similar with Islam (1/6 of the planet). His only true faith is the SBC; 18 million people which is not happy that the LDS now exceeds the SBC number in membership.

All I can say is I agree with #42 " KEEP CHURCH AND STATE SEPARATE!" This is what the founding fathers
wanted. Why do we always have to have the church in the mix of politics, why? This is so totally wrong!!!
Look what religion did to people in Europe in the middle ages. The Lutherans and Catholics were at war with each other for 30 years and killed and maimeded each other including innocent children and women. Look what the cruisaders did during the holly wars and the beat goes on in Irland. This is why religion turns me off and why I strongly believe in the separation of state and church.

The Judeo-Christian tradition generally ends in history with the revelation of God to mankind in the Hebrew Scriptures and the New Testament.

No "discovery" in the 19th century of buried golden plates are involved in Christianity, but they are in Mormonism.

Mormons do not believe Christ and the Father are one.

I'm personally leery of someone who buys into the Mormon religion, and I hope a Mormon is not the Republican candidate. If Romney's the candidate, and Obama runs again, I'd vote for the Mormon so fast your head would spin.
When can I vote for an atheist for president?

I remember back to a trip to the Moody Book store (general Christan store) and we asked if there was a Catholic section.  They told us to check the "cult" section.  So for some christians, I guess they are saying if you are anyone outside their beliefs, then you are in a "cult", Everyone knows that the word cult has a negative connotation in society that cannot be ignored, and the original definition is no longer in use.  Saying you didn't mean it by that negative definition is just a ploy to get your little smear campaign a little media attention over the weekend, and quietly retract on Monday.

Of course Mormonism is kinda goofy.

But so is Christianity.

As a Theologian, R. Albert Mohler seems to understand the Mormon faith as well as Saul understood Christ Gospel before he went to Damascus. Both Mohler and Saul were taught about God by learned men in established schools.

Saul became a new man, Paul, after his visitation by the Savior--and turned 180 degrees from his traditional education to embrace the Gospel he had previous scorned as heretical. So perhaps Mr. Mohler and the rest of the Southern Baptist Theological Seminary need to spend less time pouring over their Seminary notes and admiring their theological degrees hanging on their walls and spend more time on their knees praying and mediating before judging who is a cult and who is a true Christian. They very well may have their own "Road to Damascus" moment that will enlighten them of their errors.

Sitting here overseas watching American politics play out, I am not sure if my country is turning into Russia or Afghanistan or something of both. Between the oligarch backed tea party and the religious zealots stoning each other, it's really hard to see any of this as progress. Meanwhile my Chinese neighbors are busy doing all the things Americans used to do.

Americans are so convinced we are exceptional, that we haven't bothered to see what the rest of the world is up to. Likely there would be a big surprised if they took a look.

"Nevertheless, it rejects what orthodox Christianity affirms and it affirms what orthodox Christianity rejects."

Right. Just as Protestantism rejects much of what was once orthodox Christian (i.e., Catholic) dogma.

Robert Jeffress spoke truly.  Mormonism is a cult, but so is every other religion.  Whether Mormonism is a Christian cult or not is  a matter than cannot be  settled objectively because the concept of Christianity is essentially contested. Those who call themselves "christian" cannot agree on what actually counts as a christian. So there is no genuine concept of christianity that we all share and that we can agree on for the purposes of classifying cults.  According to the Catholic cult, all Protestant versions of Christianity are non-Christian cults.  Southern Baptists, of course, regard Catholicism as a dangerous cult. The most generous christians - liberal protestants - tend to count anyone who calls himself a "christian" a christian, but might still classify the more weirdly extreme wacko offshoots of their group cultish.  When  a religion gets very big its adherents start to think that its size is somehow evidence of its truth (ignoring the fact that there are other large cults which have doctrines which are totally incompatible with theirs).  So they start to use the term "cult" in a pejorative fashion, as code for "evil" "satanic" "doomed" etc. but those of us on the outside of the cult mentality need not use the term in that sense.  Of course, to be a member of a cult one does have to be sucked in by various irrational and sometimes pernicious doctrines.  But all religions have at least some of those.

To the person who questioned whether Roman Catholics are Christians, I would offer this brief answer: RC's worship him as the Son of God, the savior of the world and the key to the kingdom of heaven. If you need more, read a Roman Catholic book about the RC church. Not saying this contemptuously, but invitingly.

It's not up to Dr. Mohler to decide who is a Christian and who isn't. According to the Constitution, it shouldn't matter anyway; there is to be no religious test for any public office. Do those who claim to love the Constitution so much know about this part of it?
I would not vote for Mitt Romney, but it has nothing to do with his religious beliefs. Actually most of the Mormons I have known (including my dentist) seem like sensible, hard-working and honest people. (but I've never met Mr. Romney).

I am a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, (harmlessly nicknamed the "Mormon" church by those not of our faith) and I would like to remind everyone that members of our church have been serving faithfully at all levels of government for over a century. Currently, Senator Harry Reid, the Senate majority leader is a practicing member of our church. While no doubt Senator Reid's ideals and values are shaped by the church, the LDS church repeatedly reminds its members and the media that they do not affiliate with political parties, nor are they in the business of electing politicians. As to whether those of our faith are Christian, we try to remind people of our church's name: The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints. We love and worship Jesus Christ as the center of our entire religion and of our lives. We try to follow his teachings in the Bible as well as in the Book of Mormon. If you are unfamiliar with our church, please do not pass on unsubstantiated rumors. If you want to see what others of our faith have to say, please go to mormon.org.

As a Canadian living in the southern US, I find this whole issue perplexing. In a nation that pretends to believe in the separation of church and state, at election time the two are very much 'in bed together'. Ultimately it is a spiritual prostitution of the church at the hands of the state, done willingly by the church. It simply shows the parochialism of a supposedly post-modern nation. In Canada religion is never an issue in politics and most voting Canadians wouldn't know the religious preference of their political candidates. And that is the way it should be. And that's my perspective as a Christian and proud to be a Canadian.
Mr. Mohler should have had the sense to keep his mouth shut. He just dug a deeper hole.

The Bible says, "Has not God made the wisdom of the world foolish? For since in the wisdom of God the world did not come to know God through wisdom, it was the Will Of God trough the foolishness of the proclamation to save those who have faith. For Jews demand signs and Greeks look for wisdom, but we proclaim Christ crucified, a stumbling block to Jews and foolishness to Gentiles, but to those who are called, Jews and Greeks alike, Christ the Power of God and the wisdom of God. For the foolishness of God is wiser than human wisdom, and the weakness of God is stronger than human strength. " 1 Cor,1, 21-25

The Message of The Cross is Foolishness to those who are perishing (those lacking faith), but to us who are to be saved it is the power of God. For it is written: "I Will Destroy the Wisdom of the Wise, and the learning of the learned I will set aside." 1 Cor 1, 18-19

God is understood by we who have been granted faith, those who post here and obviously lack faith conform to God's words about their opinion that belief and faith is foolish. It is they who are deceived, and they mistakenly imagine they are wise. They will end up being damned by their own words if they persist in ignorance. We pray for them, but they must choose for themselves.
I love that one "Christian" thinks another "Christian" is not a "true Christian". All religion is a cult especially those cultish baptist.  This is just a group eating their young. A pox on them all.

There is no way to determine the truth of religious beliefs in general, or to settle specific concerns such as whether Mormonism is Christian or not. This is because there is no generally agreed upon standard for making such a judgment. Nor is there ever likely to be. People of all religions and belief systems need to recognize this simple fact and learn to to tolerant of one another. Tolerance is a virtue necessary to Democracy.
Why doesn't he talk about the rest of Romans 13 that says Christians shouldn't really be involved in governing at all and should accept any civil authority as chosen by God?

Jesus was a young Jewish guy who had no job or other visible means of support.  He was not married, had no girlfriend and hung out with 12 other young men.  He advocated loving one's enemies, hating sin but not sinners and paying ones taxes.  He also stated that it was easier for a camel to pass through the eye of a needle than for a rich man to enter Heaven.  If someone like this were to run for president would he ever gain the support of right-wing evangelicals?

What fools these mortals be.

Here we are facing serious economic problems and these kindergartner-equivalents are squabbling about who is really Christian.

I neither know nor care. Let's talk instead about who has good ideas and who can convince the citizenry that we're wasting precious time on nonsense.

The Book Of Morman is to the NT what The Koran is to the OT.
Both have a revered prophet that seems to compete with God.

As a Mormon and a Democrat, I say let them attack Romney any way they like.

If you want to know about the LDS church, primary source info is at mormon.org and lds.org. Criticize my faith all you want (and our politicians--from both parties--all you want), but at least do a little reading first.

You Go Girl! I am the 99%. I am a person, and not a corporation. I contribute to progressive campaigns. I live in MA, and I vote. And I can't WAIT to VOTE FOR ELIZABETH WARREN! You get'm girl!

A vote for Warren is a vote for the People. (Go Obama, too!)

If I were Scott Brown, I would give the JOBS BILL a lot more consideration than the other Republicans and then vote YES for it to pass.

Just a suggestion....
